Preface
The primary innovation of this text is a new perspective on teaching the theory
of integration. Most introductory analysis courses focus initially on the Riemann in-
tegral, with other definitions discussed later (if at all). The paradigm being proposed
is that the Riemann integral and the “generalized Riemann integral” should be con-
sidered simultaneously, not separately – in the same manner as uniform continuity
and continuity. (Indeed, if it were not for historical and practical impediments, the
term uniform integrability would be preferable to Riemann integrability.) One defi-
nition is not superior to the other. Riemann integrability is simply a special case of
integrability, with particular properties that are worth noting.
This point of view has implications for the treatment of other topics. Because the
definition of the integral is stated in terms of gauges, it makes sense to translate this
perspective to continuity and differentiability as well. Besides creating a smoother
transition between chapters, this approach mitigates some longstanding pedagogical
difficulties. For example, the manner in which uniform continuity is typically ex-
plained can be unnecessarily confusing. For someone unfamiliar with the relevant
properties, the statements “for every x, for every ε, there exists a δ such that ...” and
“for every ε, there exists a δ such that ... for every x” may be difficult to distinguish.
Even though the difference is semantic, it seems more natural to ask whether a gauge 2
(a function that assumes only positive values) can be taken to be constant. The
text also emphasizes the concept of uniform differentiability, which rarely receives
much attention. This property has important implications to the continuity of the
derivative, which is one of the major themes of Chapter 3.
Because of the initial emphasis on continuity, differentiability, and integrability,
mostofthematerialrelatingtosequencesandserieshasbeendeferreduntilChapter5.
ThetreatmentofsequencesinChapter1focusesonafewessentialtopics, particularly
the Cauchy Criterion. The proof of the Cauchy Criterion is somewhat different from
what appears in most textbooks, in that it does not rely on subsequences and the
Bolzano–Weierstrass Theorem. Removing this “efficiency” allows for an argument
that deals more directly with the core concepts.
Although it is largely independent of the issues discussed above, it is worth noting
that Chapter 3 includes several concrete examples of functions with discontinuous
derivative. Inmanybooks,h(t) = t2sin(1/t)istheonlysuchfunctionthatisexplicitly
mentioned. Despite its historical significance, this example may be perceived as a
deus ex machina, particularly if the trigonometric functions have not been formally
introduced. To understand the consequences of Darboux’s Theorem, it is important
to develop a solid intuition about the behavior of the functions to which it pertains.
Chapter 5 consists primarily of standard results relating to sequences and series,
with two substantial additions. First of all, Raabe’s Test is discussed in more detail
than in other texts, with an emphasis on its connection to p-series. Secondly, Section
5.5 is devoted entirely to the subject of Cesa`ro convergence. To the best of my
knowledge, this is the first textbook to include a proof of Schep’s Inequality (Theorem
5.36). 3
Remarks to new mathematicians
Everymathematicianmustmakethetransitionatsomepointfromcomputationally-
oriented mathematics (e.g., calculus, differential equations, linear algebra) to proof-
based mathematics (e.g., real analysis, abstract algebra, topology). I often describe
this process as the evolution from a student of mathematics to a mathematician. The
distinction is that a student’s main objective is to “find an answer,” while the primary
responsibility of a mathematician is to understand and construct proofs.
This transition can take place in the context of any branch of mathematics, al-
though it is particularly common for real analysis to serve as the point of entry. In
addition to its intrinsic importance, real analysis directly relates to material most stu-
dents have encountered before (continuity, derivatives, integrals, and series). While
mastery of calculus is no guarantee of success in analysis, familiarity with the basic
concepts is certainly helpful.
Mathematics is not a spectator sport. The exercises at the end of each chapter
provideanopportunitytoengageactivelywiththematerial. Ifpossible, takethetime
to complete them all. Exercises marked with an asterisk are particularly important
to the overall exposition and should not be skipped.
When completing the exercises, the objective is not simply to “find a proof that
works.” Mathematics that has not been clearly communicated has not been fully un-
derstood. A large part of becoming a mathematician consists of learning to write
mathematics clearly and effectively. I would recommend keeping the following guide-
lines in mind:
(1) Write in complete sentences. Use proper spelling, grammar, punctuation, and
syntax. Do not use needless abbreviations (such as “b/c” or “w/o”). 4
(2) Employ mathematical notation wisely. Avoid symbols when words would work
equally well. Incorporate your notation into your sentence structure. Treat
lengthy equations as you would a lengthy quotation.
(a) Apieceofsymbolicnotationshouldalwaysrepresenteitheraspecificobject
or a complete phrase, and should not be used simply as an abbreviation.
For example, never write “Whenever x ≤ all of the elements in our set, ...”
(b) Never begin a sentence with a piece of symbolic notation. Never juxtapose
two distinct pieces of notation without putting some verbiage between
them. For example, never write “If x ∈ X, x ≥ 1.”
(3) Always make sure it is completely clear what you are trying to do. If you are
attempting to prove a particular proposition, state the claim explicitly. If you
are trying to give a counterexample to a certain hypothesis, explain exactly
what it is you would like to show.
(4) Edit your mathematical writing for style, correctness, and content.
(5) Have a specific audience in mind when you are writing. Envision your reader
as a mathematician at the appropriate level, but one who has not worked the
exercises you are presenting. Think about what details you would need to see
in order to understand a particular argument.
I have done my best to follow these principles while composing this text. For anyone
interested in a further discussion of mathematical writing, I particularly recommend
an article by Paul Halmos [30].
Newer mathematicians may be surprised by the number of exercises that ask the
reader to construct a particular example. Some of these examples are fairly straight- 5
forward, while others require more ingenuity. Never underestimate the importance
of an example, even a seemingly trivial one. An example can be just as powerful as
a theorem, as it can demonstrate the falseness of an assertion. An example can also
be a precursor to a theorem, providing specific evidence that leads to a more general
observation.
There is a brief set of historical notes following every chapter. While this text
does not purport to be an historical treatise, it is important to consider the context
in which the theory was developed. Readers are encouraged to learn more about
historical questions they find interesting, either by perusing the references listed in
the bibliography or by conducting their own research. 6

0.1 Sets
The building block of modern mathematics is the set. While the concept can be
described in a more technical manner, we will think of a set as being a well-defined
collection of distinct objects. The elements, or items within a set, may be numbers,

are both sets. We frequently use braces to demarcate a set and commas to distinguish

For a natural number n, we write [n] to denote the set {1,2,...,n}. A set con-
sisting of a single element is often called a singleton set. The empty set, denoted ∅, is
defined to be the set consisting of no elements. The similarity between the symbols
∅ and 0 can sometimes lead to confusion. Note that {0} represents the singleton set
consisting of the number 0, while ∅ signifies a set without any elements. It might be
clearer to write {} instead of ∅, but that notation is not commonly employed.
Rather than listing all the elements of a set explicitly, we will often use what is
called set-builder notation to describe the elements in terms of some rule or relation.
For example, {k ∈ Z : k ≥ 1} indicates the set of all integers that are greater than
or equal to 1 (which would be another way of denoting N). Similarly, for any natural
number n, we could write [n] as {k ∈ N : 1 ≤ k ≤ n}. Despite its superficial
appearance, it is possible for a set defined in this fashion to be empty; for example,
{s ∈ R : s2 < 0} contains no elements.
One of our major points of interest will be the relationship between sets. We say
that a set A is a subset of a set B if every element of A also belongs to B. A subset
A of B is called a proper subset if there is an element of B that does not belong to A.
For example, N is a proper subset of Z, since every natural number is an integer and
there is at least one integer that is not a natural number. We often use the notation
A ⊆ B to indicate that A is a subset of B, writing A ⊂ B when we know that A is
a proper subset of B. (Readers should be aware that older texts sometimes use the
symbol ⊂ to denote a subset, with (cid:40) or (cid:36) signifying a proper subset.)
For a pair of sets A and B, we say that A = B whenever both A ⊆ B and B ⊆ A; 9
that is, A and B contain exactly the same elements. This principle, often known as
mutual inclusion, is not only the definition for two sets being equal, but the standard
method of proof as well. (See, for example, the proof of Proposition 0.1.)

We will now introduce another property of N, which many readers may not have
encountered previously.
Proposition 0.5 (Well-Ordering Principle) Every nonempty subset A of N contains
a least element. In other words, there is an element m of A such that m ≤ k for all
k in A.
We will view this property as an axiomatic assumption, rather than a result that
requires a proof. (See also Exercise 1.10.) As we shall see, this principle has several
indispensable consequences. First and foremost, it gives rise to a powerful tool for
verifying results that are stated in terms of the natural numbers.
Proposition 0.6 (Principle of Mathematical Induction) Let P(k) denote a propo-
sition stated in terms of a natural number k. Suppose that P(1) is true. If, for every
natural number k, we can show that P(k) being true implies that P(k +1) is true,
then P(k) is true for all k in N.
The main idea underlying this principle is that, if P(k) is not true for all k, then
the set
A = {k ∈ N : P(k) is false}
is nonempty. Hence the Well-Ordering Principle dictates that A must have a least
element m. By assumption, we know that 1 does not belong to A, so m ≥ 2. Thus
m−1 is a natural number which, based on the definition of m, cannot belong to A.
Therefore P(m−1) is true, which implies that P(m) is also true. Hence m does not 15
belong to A, which is a contradiction. Therefore A must be empty, which means that
P(k) must be true for every natural number k.
As this argument may seem somewhat abstract, we will provide several examples
that illustrate how mathematical induction tends to be applied in practice.

Consider a pair of sets A and B. A function f: A → B is a rule that assigns

0.4 Cardinality
We begin this section with a basic distinction relating to the number of elements
in a set.
Definition 0.15 A set A is finite if either A = ∅ or there is a bijection f: [n] → A
for some natural number n. Any set that is not finite is called infinite.
We will take it as self-evident that the set N, and any set containing N, is infinite.
On the other hand, a proper subset of N may be either finite or infinite.
Example 0.16 Consider the set A = {2,4,8,16}. The function f: [4] → A given
by the rule f(k) = 2k is a bijection, which means (as one would have expected) that
the set A is finite.

claim that P is infinite. Suppose, to the contrary, that there is a bijection f: [n] → P
for some natural number n. In other words, every prime number can be uniquely

The cardinality of a finite set A, which we denote |A|, is simply the number of
elements in A. In other words, if there is a bijection f: [n] → A, we would say that
|A| = n. Similarly, we take |∅| to be 0. The same concept applies to infinite sets,
although there are certain technical considerations that must be taken into account.
Definition 0.18 Consider a pair of sets A and B.
(1) We say that |A| = |B| if there is a bijection f: A → B.
(2) We say that |A| ≤ |B| if there is an injection g: A → B.
(3) We say that |A| < |B| if there is an injection g: A → B, but no bijection
f: A → B.
For these definitions to make sense, we would want to know that |A| = |B| when-
ever both |A| ≤ |B| and |B| ≤ |A|; in other words, there is a bijection f: A → B
whenever there are injections g: A → B and h: B → A. This fact, known as the
Schr¨oder–Bernstein Theorem, is actually true, although we will not attempt to pro-
vide a proof. (See [1, p. 32] for an outline of the argument.) Theorem 0.25 can be
viewed as a weaker version of this result.
Example 0.19 Define the function g: N → Q by the rule g(n) = n. This function is
clearly injective (but not surjective), so |N| ≤ |Q|. Proposition 0.27 will demonstrate
that |N| = |Q|.
Example 0.20 Define the function g: N → R by the rule g(n) = n. As above, the
injectivity of g shows that |N| ≤ |R|. The question of whether |N| = |R| or |N| < |R|
will be addressed in Chapter 1. 24
When we are working with infinite cardinalities, the set N provides a yardstick
against which all other sets are measured.
Definition 0.21 A set A is countably infinite if there is a bijection f: N → A. An
infinite set that is not countably infinite is called uncountable or uncountably infinite.
In other words, A is countably infinite if and only if |N| = |A|. The term countable
is often used to describe a set that is either finite or countably infinite. Some authors,
however, take countable to refer only to countably infinite sets, so we will refrain from
using this term to avoid ambiguity.
Example 0.22 Let 2N denote the set of all even natural numbers. Define the
function f: N → 2N by the rule f(k) = 2k. It is easy to verify that this function is
a bijection, which means that N and 2N have the same cardinality. In particular, 2N
is countably infinite.
While the preceding example is fairly straightforward, it may seem paradoxical
that a proper subset of N can have the same cardinality as N. Although such a
situation cannot occur in the context of finite sets, it is entirely typical for infinite
sets.

Theorem 0.25 Let A be an infinite set.
(1) If there exists an injection g: A → N, then A is countably infinite.
(2) If there exists a surjection h: N → A, then A is countably infinite.
Proof. (1) Suppose g: A → N is injective and consider the image g(A) ⊆ N. Since g
is injective, the function g: A → g(A) is a bijection. Since A is infinite, g(A) is an
infinite subset of N with the same cardinality as A. Proposition 0.24 shows that g(A)
must be countably infinite, which means that A must also be countably infinite.
(2) Suppose h: N → A is surjective. In other words, for an arbitrary element
a of A, there is at least one natural number k such that h(k) = a. There may be 27
more than one such k in N for any particular a in A, so define g(a) to be the smallest
natural number that is taken by h to a. Thus we have defined a function g: A → N.
Moreover, if there are a and b in A such that g(a) = g(b), the definition of g shows
that

Therefore g: A → N is injective, so part (1) shows that A is countably infinite.

1.1 Real Numbers and Rational Numbers
Although we will not rigorously construct the set of real numbers, for the moment
we will assume both its existence and its basic properties. The set R, along with
the operations of addition and multiplication, constitutes a field. In other words, it
satisfies the following conditions: 43
(f1) Associativity: (a+b)+c = a+(b+c) and (ab)c = a(bc) for all a, b, and c in R.
(f2) Commutativity: a+b = b+a and ab = ba for all a and b in R.
(f3) Distributivity: a(b+c) = ab+ac for all a, b, and c in R.
(f4) Identities: There exist distinct elements 0 and 1 in R such that a+0 = a and
a·1 = a for all a in R.
(f5) Additive inverse: For every a in R, there exists an element −a in R such that
a+(−a) = 0.
(f6) Multiplicative inverse: For every nonzero a in R, there exists an element a−1 in
R such that a·a−1 = 1.
Moreover, the following properties hold with regard to the standard order relation:
(o1) For any pair of elements a and b in R, either a ≤ b or b ≤ a (or possibly both).
(o2) If a ≤ b and b ≤ a, then a = b.
(o3) If a ≤ b and b ≤ c, then a ≤ c.
(o4) If a ≤ b, then a+c ≤ b+c.
(o5) If a ≥ 0 and b ≥ 0, then ab ≥ 0.
We describe R, together with the appropriate operations and order relation, as an
ordered field. The reader would be correct to observe that the set Q of rational
numbers, with the same operations and order relation, also constitutes an ordered
field. What sets R apart is its behavior with regard to upper and lower bounds. 44
Definition 1.1 A nonempty subset A of R is bounded above if there is a real number
M such that t ≤ M for all t in A. In this situation, M is called an upper bound for
A. Likewise, A is bounded below if there is a real number m such that m ≤ t for all
t in A, in which case m is called a lower bound for A. A set that is both bounded
above and bounded below is called bounded.
Definition 1.2 A real number M is called a supremum or least upper bound for a
nonempty subset A of R if it satisfies two conditions:
• The number M is an upper bound for A.
• If M(cid:48) is another upper bound for A, then M ≤ M(cid:48).
Likewise, a real number m is called an infimum or greatest lower bound for A if:
• The number m is a lower bound for A.
• If m(cid:48) is another lower bound for A, then m(cid:48) ≤ m.

Theorem 1.3 (Supremum Property) Any nonempty subset of R that is bounded
above has a supremum in R. 45
In the context of this definition, the supremum of a set A must belong to R, but
not necessarily to A itself. This property is not an intuitive assumption, but a guiding
principle in the construction of the real numbers (which is beyond the scope of our
present discussion). While this condition is typically stated in terms of suprema, it
could equivalently be phrased in terms of infima (see Exercise 1.1).

a set A belongs to A, we refer to the infimum as the minimum of A, denoted minA.

2.1 Continuity and Uniform Continuity
Anyone reading this book has presumably encountered the concept of continuity
in some guise, whether as an intuitive notion relating to the behavior of a curve or
a precise property stated in terms of functional limits. The treatment in this text
will be slightly different. We begin with a remarkably simple definition, which will
tie together the main concepts presented in Chapters 2, 3, and 4.
Definition 2.1 Let A be a subset of R. A function δ(t): A → R is called a gauge
on A if δ(t) > 0 for all t in A. 77
There are no additional conditions imposed on such a function; it simply assigns a
positive number to each point in A. We will include the argument t for notational
clarity, except when a gauge is constant. A gauge provides a convenient vehicle for
discussing the behavior of a function over an entire set.
Recall that we are using the symbol I to denote an arbitrary nondegenerate
interval. Unless otherwise noted, we will assume henceforth that the term interval
refers only to a nondegenerate interval.
Definition 2.2 A function f: I → R is continuous on a subset A of I if, for every
positive number ε, there is a gauge δ(t) on A such that
|f(s)−f(t)| < ε
whenever the point s belongs to I, the point t belongs to A, and |s−t| < δ(t).
Although we will rarely mention this fact explicitly, to avoid a triviality we will
generally assume that A is nonempty.
Definition 2.3 A functionf: I → Rthat is continuous onA ⊆ I is calleduniformly
continuous on A if, for every positive number ε, the corresponding gauge δ(t) can be
taken to be a constant function.

Historical Notes
(1) Although there had been precursors throughout the 18th century, the modern
formulation of continuity began to emerge in the early 19th century. As in the
case of suprema and Cauchy sequences, Bolzano’s 1817 treatise represented the
first substantial progress towards a rigorous definition:
According to a correct definition, the expression that a function fx
varies according to the law of continuity for all values of x inside
or outside certain limits means only that, if x is any such value, the
difference f(x+ω)−fx can be made smaller than any given quantity,
provided ω can be taken as small as we please.
Once again, this perspective was popularized and refined by other mathemati-
cians, particularly Augustin-Louis Cauchy and Karl Weierstrass (1815–1897).
(2) The special case of the Intermediate Value Theorem for L = 0 is sometimes
called Bolzano’s Theorem. In fact, the (rather lengthy) title of the aforemen-
tioned treatise from 1817 may be translated as Purely Analytic Proof of the
Theorem that between any two Values, which give Results of Opposite Sign, 101
there lies at least one real Root of the Equation. Bolzano actually stated a more
general result:
If two functions of x, fx and ϕx, vary according to the law of conti-
nuity either for all values of x or for all those lying between α and
β, and furthermore if fα < ϕα and fβ > ϕβ, then there is always a
certain value of x between α and β for which fx = ϕx.
This theorem (and its application to polynomials) was Bolzano’s primary mo-
tivation for developing what we now consider to be many of the fundamental
concepts in analysis.
(3) The property of uniform continuity took longer to develop. Although the con-
cept was foreshadowed by other mathematicians, the formal definition did not
appear in print until 1870 (in a paper by Eduard Heine). Likewise, while
Bolzano and Dirichlet were both aware of the result of Theorem 2.16, the proof
was first published in 1872 (also in a paper by Heine). See [19] and [49] for
more details.
(4) The criterion introduced in Exercise 2.23, which could be called the Sequential
Characterization of Uniform Continuity, was stated by David Burton and John

Historical Notes
(1) The history of the derivative, which spans several centuries, is too complicated
to discuss in detail. Isaac Newton (1642–1726) devised the concept of a flux-
ion in 1665. Joseph-Louis Lagrange (1736–1813) introduced the term derived 135
function (“fonction d´eriv´ee”) in 1797. Augustin-Louis Cauchy presented a con-
cept similar to the modern definition of the derivative in his Cours d’analyse,
published in 1821.
(2) Edward Charles Titchmarsh (1899–1963) may have been the first person to
use the term uniformly differentiable, although he did not provide an explicit
definition (see [53, p. 76]). Walter Rudin (1921–2010) introduced the concept as
part of an exercise relating to the result of Theorem 3.23 (see [48, pp. 114–115]).
(3) Fermat’s Theorem is named after Pierre de Fermat (1607–1665), who popular-
ized a related technique for finding maxima and minima. The result presented
inthischaptershouldnotbeconfusedwithFermat’sLittleTheoremorFermat’s
Last Theorem, both of which pertain to number theory.
(4) MichelRolle(1652–1719)publishedaproofofRolle’sTheoremin1691,although
the original version was limited to polynomials.
(5) The Mean Value Theorem is often attributed to Lagrange, and is sometimes
called either Lagrange’s Mean Value Theorem or simply Lagrange’s Theorem.
While his treatment of the derivative was rather different from the modern
approach, Lagrange did employ techniques comparable to the Mean Value The-
orem. Cauchy proved a more standard form of the Mean Value Theorem in a
treatise published in 1823, at which point he also introduced the Generalized
Mean Value Theorem (see Exercise 3.23). Cauchy’s proofs required the un-
stated hypothesis that f(cid:48) is continuous on [a,b]. Giuseppe Peano (1858–1932)
established his version of the Mean Value Theorem (see Exercise 3.24) in 1884. 136
(6) Darboux’s Theorem is named after Gaston Darboux (1842–1917), who pub-
lished the result in 1875. His initial example of a function with discontinuous
derivative is presented in Exercise 3.8.

Historical Notes
(1) As in the case of the derivative, the integral has a long and complicated his-
tory. While there were foreshadowings of the integral in classical antiquity, the
(cid:82)
modern concept began to emerge in the 17th century. The symbol , standing 195
for summa, was first used by Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646–1716) in 1675.
The term integral appeared in print for the first time in 1690, in the writings
of Jacob Bernoulli.
(2) The formulation of the integral presented in this text is often referred to as
the Henstock–Kurzweil integral, the generalized Riemann integral, or the gauge
integral. We have eschewed all those names, to emphasize the primacy of this
definition. While there had been several precursors, the majority of the relevant
theory was developed by Ralph Henstock (1923–2007) and Jaroslav Kurzweil
(1926–2022), beginning in the mid-1950s.
(3) Bernhard Riemann (1826–1866) introduced his definition of the integral in late
1853,althoughitwasnotpublisheduntil1868. Riemann’sversionoftheintegral
hasbecomeubiquitousattheundergraduatelevel, althoughitisoftenpresented
in a manner more consistent with Darboux’s treatment (e.g., Theorem 4.28).
(4) Cousin’s Lemma is derived from a result proved by Pierre Cousin (1867–1933)
in 1895. Cousin’s work did not explicitly refer to gauges, although it did relate
to the Heine–Borel Property.
(5) Theorem 4.28 was established by Gaston Darboux in 1875, in the same paper in
which he proved his eponymous theorem. (See Exercise 4.15, which also relates
to Darboux’s characterization of integrability.) The lower sum L(f,P) and the
upper sum U(f,P), introduced in Section 4.4, are often called Darboux sums.
(6) It would be impossible to attribute the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to
any single mathematician. James Gregory (1638–1675), Isaac Barrow, Isaac
Newton, and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz all made important contributions, as 196
did later mathematicians such as Cauchy. One of the complicating factors is
that there are multiple versions of the theorem, which vary depending on the
particulardefinitionoftheintegral. Forexample, Theorem4.36wouldnolonger
be valid if we restricted ourselves to Riemann’s definition. (To be more specific,
the integrability of F(cid:48) = f would be an assumption, not a conclusion of the
theorem.)
(7) The term logarithm (“logarithmus”) was introduced by John Napier (1550–
1617) in 1614, although his construction differs greatly from the modern func-
tion. Alphonse Antonio de Sarasa (1618–1667), writing in 1649, was the first
to note the connection between a logarithm and the area beneath a hyperbola.

There are many other methods of extending the notion of convergence for se-
quences and series. Perhaps the most robust is the Banach limit, which assigns a
(not always uniquely determined) value to any bounded sequence. This technique is
an application of the Hahn–Banach Theorem, one of the fundamental results in the
branch of mathematics known as functional analysis. See [15, pp. 82–83] for more
details.

despite the absence of any demonstrable connection with the ancient Babyloni-
